data.title: Build Atom for 32 bit Linux
data.body:
I'm attempting to build the latest version (1.11.2 & 1.12.0b5) on Fedora 24 for 32 bit platform.

Upon starting the build script, I immediately get this erro:

/usr/local/src/atom-1.12.0-beta5/script/build:13
const yargs = require('yargs')
^^^^^
SyntaxError: Use of const in strict mode.
    at exports.runInThisContext (vm.js:73:16)
    at Module._compile (module.js:443:25)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:478:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:355:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:310:12)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:501:10)
    at startup (node.js:129:16)
    at node.js:814:3

Am I just out of luck building 32 bit versions?

data.title: Add flatpak support
Windows 7 Atom install failure
data.body:
Checklist:
Safe mode doesn't apply, can't install. Latest version, check. Debugging guide & FAQ read. Did a basic search on issues, found nothing useful. My AV - real time protection from Windows Security Essentials - is turned off.

I can't install the latest version of Atom. I get an incomperehensible windows exception error, than a notification about the failed update.

See log below, and thanks very much in advance for your help. I need to use this text editor for an entry-level programming tutorial, so I'm not super-savvy.:

data.title: `grammar-used` activation hooks don't trigger on package activation when grammar is currently used by open editors
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)? **N/A**
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Packages using `grammar-used` activation hooks don't actually reactivate if disabled and then re-enabled in settings, even if they were active prior _and_ there are editors currently using hooked grammar.

In particular, they don't trigger on package update, which is confusing to end-users (see e.g. https://github.com/atom-haskell/ide-haskell-repl/issues/39)

FWIW, I see these options to fix this:
1. When package is enabled, check for currently open editors using relevant grammar and trigger `grammar-used` hook
2. Store `grammar-used` trigger state per-window and trigger newly-loaded packages
3. Store `grammar-used` trigger state per-package per-window

Of course, there's a fourth option of 'wontfix' but it'd be kind of sad.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install [activation-hook-test](https://github.com/lierdakil/activation-hook-test) package (not published, clone from git, there are no dependencies, so `apm link` should be enough)
2. Open an `.md` file or select `Github Markdown` grammar for a currently open file -- bottom panel will show up:
   
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7275622/19785541/68752d78-9ca2-11e6-85fd-ae6fedae7624.png)
   If it doesn't, make sure `Github Markdown` grammar is selected.
3. Disable activation-hook-test package -- bottom panel will disappear
4. Enable activation-hook-test package

**Expected behavior:** Bottom panel reappears

**Actual behavior:** Bottom panel doesn't appear. But it does when reproduction step 2 is re-done.
### Versions

OS: Gentoo Linux, x86_64

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 3.4.5
git 2.10.1
```

data.title: Update transpilation pipeline
data.body:
Currently, the Atom transpilation story, via the compile cache, is as follows:
- All TypeScript (`.ts`) files are compiled with the TypeScript compiler.
- All CoffeeScript (`.coffee`) files are compiled with the CoffeeScript compiler.
- JavaScript (`.js`) files are compiled with the Babel compiler _if_ they start with `/** @babel */`, `"use babel"`, `'use babel'`, or `/* @flow */`. Atom currently uses Babel 5 to transpile JS, and sets some explicit options in `static/babelrc.json`.

In addition, the `ThemeManager` uses `LessCompileCache` to compile Less (`.less`) files to CSS.

In an ideal world, individual packages would have more control over how exactly their source is transpiled before being run in Atom. A best case scenario would be that a package author can specify _exactly_ how we should transform their source. At a minimum, packages should be able to pick-and-choose which JavaScript transformations are applied to them by specifying their own options in a local `.babelrc` and including any additional Babel plugins as appropriate.

To start with, I'm updating Babel to version 6 while attempting to keep the resulting JavaScript as similar to the Babel 5 version as possible, to avoid breaking existing packages.
- [x] Update to Babel 6
  - [ ] Include appropriate plugins to mimic Babel 5 behavior
- [ ] Figure out backward-compat opt-out story (e.g. pragma)
- [ ] Figure out local customizations (including ones with package-specific options, like Relay schema location)
- [ ] Other stuff

/cc @atom/core @nathansobo

data.title: Alt-modified keystrokes are broken on macOS in 1.12.0-beta4
Shelling out to collect environment variables is creating runaway 100% CPU processes on Linux
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

I'm fairly sure this will end up being an Electron issue, but here goes ...

When I start atom-beta (1.12.0b4, though was present with b3 at least), it spawns a shell ('env') subprocess which burns 100% CPU, attempting to read stdin forever:

```
systemd,1,1 --system --deserialize 126
  ├─atom,15392,10213
  │   ├─atom,15403,10213
  │   │   └─atom,15466,10213
  │   │       ├─zsh,15497,10213 -ilc command env
```

strace on the shell shows this looping forever:

```
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_SETMASK, [], [TSTP TTIN TTOU], 8) = 0
read(0, NULL, 0)                        = 0
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_BLOCK, [TSTP TTIN TTOU], [], 8) = 0
getpgrp()                               = 10213
ioctl(15, TIOCGPGRP, [11445])           = 0
getpgrp()                               = 10213
ioctl(15, TIOCGPGRP, [11445])           = 0
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_SETMASK, [], [TSTP TTIN TTOU], 8) = 0
read(0, NULL, 0)                        = 0
rt_sigprocmask(SIG_BLOCK, [TSTP TTIN TTOU], [], 8) = 0
```

Sometimes this process blocks Atom startup, and you have to kill the shell for Atom's window to show. Sometimes Atom works just fine despite this, and you only realise later when you wonder why your system is slow, and kill the extraneous process. Sometimes closing Atom takes the rogue shell process with it, and sometimes it outlives Atom. Sometimes everything works fine and I can't reproduce it at all.

Either way, safe mode or not has no effect on it, and nothing bright turns up with `--enable-logging`. Timecop shows 'window load time' taking an ungodly amount of time, but with no insight into why.

Happy to supply more details or attempt debugging as needed, with the caveat that I have no idea what I'm doing in JavaScript.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Have my system
2. Run Atom beta

**Expected behavior:** 'What a nice normal text-editing experience this is'

**Actual behavior:** WOOOOOOOOSSHHHH goes the laptop fan
### Versions

Atom 1.12.0b4 (also occurred with b3)
Fedora 25 (kernel 4.8-rc8+, glibc 2.24, etc)

data.title: Update README.md
Remove --harmony JavaScript flag
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Because the newer versions of Chromium (v52 in Atom v1.12.0-beta4) we're using in the current versions of Atom support all of the critical pieces of ES6, the `--harmony` flag is no longer necessary. Since the `--harmony` flag was the only flag set in that function, I also removed the `setupJavascriptArguments` function and the one call to the function.
### Alternate Designs

v1.4.x of Electron, which is based on Chromium v53, doesn't suffer from the bug that the `--harmony` flag exposes. Our [Electron v1.4 update PR](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/12696) is still not quite ready to merge, so we decided to just remove the flag.
### Benefits

People won't experience random crashes when executing async code in Atom v1.12.x and above.
### Possible Drawbacks

There may be some packages that rely on features provided by `--harmony` that aren't available in the vanilla JavaScript support in Chromium or less likely aren't available in Atom's Babel support.
### Applicable Issues

Fixes #13073

data.title: Sign Windows builds with sha256 and timestamp
Text file associated with Atom, it's file icon is an empty white rectangle, which causes by Windows register error
data.body:
Atom Version : Windows 10, 1.11.2

Problem:
Associated all text file(like .java/.txt) with atom, but on Windows, these file icons are  an empty white rectangle, seems like unknown file type.

Reason:
I have found the reason caused the problem in Windows register,
`HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\atom.exe\DefaultIcon`
After install , the term value refers to 
`"C:\Users\Admin\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.11.2\resources\cli\file.ico"`
but actually, file.ico file is not exited in this path, 

Solution:
as I modified as 
`C:\Users\Admin\AppData\Local\atom\app.ico`,  it works.

data.title: Capitalize save in button label so keybindings work
data.body:
Specifying the button label as `Don't Save` instead of `Don't save` allows the keybindings of `cmd-d` and `cmd-delete` to be used on macOS to select this button.

Looks like this might have regressed in https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/4e9048d22de5fce1fb4bce20515fcee96aae786d#diff-1a7d1dda35d8e7ed3ad35b9a9fd2f134L596 and https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/4e9048d22de5fce1fb4bce20515fcee96aae786d#diff-1a7d1dda35d8e7ed3ad35b9a9fd2f134R584

data.title: 1.11.2 - language settings (tabType/indent_style) seemingly ignored on window:refresh, restart
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- ~~[ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?~~ Can **_you_**?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- ~~[ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?~~
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Language-X packages can have their own editor settings, and snippets. However I found that tabType/indent_style is not respected when starting/restarting/window:reloading atom. 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set your global preference for tabs to auto, 2 spaces and check show invisibles. Inject a settings file in your favorite language-X package:

``` coffeescript
'.scope.Name':
  'editor':
    'tabType': 'hard' #this doesn't seem to do anything.
    'softWrap': true
    'indent_style': 'tab' #this actually makes it an \x09
```
1. do a window:reload, type a tab when back up. Should be a tab character, but it's two spaces.
2. Quit Atom and restart it, type a tab in the file after session is restored, it's again two spaces.
3. Change something in the `settings/language-X.cson` file and save it, do a window:reload. You might now get a tab character, or you might get two spaces. Can't see a pattern, seems random.

**Expected behavior:** settings/language-X.cson should **always** override global settings.

**Actual behavior:** ([screencast of bug in action](https://bugout.regex.cf/tabissues.mp4)) settings/language-X.cson seems to randomly be reloaded when modified, or only when switching to another language and then back to this one.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
OS: 10.10.5

data.title: Find and replace not working for a lookahead pattern
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)? **Yes**
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? **Yes**
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? **Yes**
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? **Yes**
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? **Yes**
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? **Yes**
### Description

Regular expression find and replace does not work given a lookahead pattern.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a buffer containing some text to search over. For instance, `const object = { 'key': 'value' }`
2. Open find-and-replace (Ctrl-F or Cmd-F) and turn Regex on.
3. Enter a search string containing a lookahead in the Find field (for instance, `'(?=.*:)`), and click Find. Notice that the matched strings are properly highlighted.
4. Click "Replace" or "Replace All".

**Expected behavior:** One or all of the strings are replaced with the given replacement string (or deleted if the replace field is blank).

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens.
### Versions

1.11.2, Windows 10.0.14393 Build 14393

1.11.2 and earlyer

data.title: 1.12 releases
Atom as a daemon
data.body:
This was already brought up and dismissed in issue #6352, but this is _not_ about startup time. (Although that is a neat side-effect ;)

One of my favorite features of Emacs is that I can [run it as a daemon](https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/EmacsAsDaemon) and even [start it as a systemd service](https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/EmacsAsDaemon#toc8).

When emacs-server is running, I can make another window instantly with emacsclient and have access to all of the buffers that I had open already.

On top of this, if emacs is running as a systemd service, I get the same advantages as before, but now that instance of emacs-server is already running before I start emacs, so every new window
- has access to all of the buffers I had open before
- starts within milliseconds

and the server keeps running **even when all the windows are closed.**

How difficult would it be to implement this in Atom?
